Comment: Soooooo many people here didn't read the article.  **This award is a nod in agreement with Trump's claim that the interview was edited**. It was nominated for "outstanding edited interview", and **not on any grounds related to journalistic integrity**.   > The interview featuring then-Democratic presidential nominee Harris has been at the center of Trump's legal action against CBS, which he accuses of "deceptively editing" Harris' responses to make her appear more competent than she was. **The Emmy nod adds an ironic twist, recognizing the same editing Trump seeks legal retribution for.**   Apparently Emmys can be awarded to random interviews based on arbitrary criteria. This was probably paid for by the Trump team, so they have some legal ammo in claiming that a (supposedly) independent institution recognized the same allegations claimed by Trump's legal team.

Comment: Thing is though, even assuming their edit *was* deceptive (it wasn't), cases need damages. What damage can his lawyers argue, that he could have double won the election had this interview been edited how *he thinks* it should have? That's worth $20,000,000,000 in damages?  As well, assuming a wacky world where they actually succeeded, they've then set the legal precedent that news stations can be sued for multiple billions for having a perceived bias - that's pretty much lights-out for every news station, especially Fox, OANN, etc.  I think it's just a legal shakedown, and I don't think they're trying to build the case up cause it doesn't have any merit to begin with.
